problem: Define $f(x)=3x-8$. If $f^{-1}$ is the inverse of $f$, find the value(s) of $x$ for which $f(x)=f^{-1}(x)$.
solution: Substituting $f^{-1}(x)$ into our expression for $f$ we get  \[f(f^{-1}(x))=3f^{-1}(x)-8.\]Since $f(f^{-1}(x))=x$ for all $x$ in the domain of $f^{-1}$, we have \[x=3f^{-1}(x)-8.\]or  \[f^{-1}(x)=\frac{x+8}3.\]We want to solve the equation $f(x) = f^{-1}(x)$, so \[3x-8=\frac{x+8}3.\]or \[9x-24=x+8.\]Solving for $x$, we find $x = \boxed{4}$.
chatgpt_solution: We want to find the value(s) of $x$ for which $f(x) = f^{-1}(x)$. Letting $f(x) = y$, this means $y = f^{-1}(x)$. Therefore we have \[y = f^{-1}(x) \iff f(y) = f(f^{-1}(x)).\]Since $f(x) = 3x-8$, we substitute to get \[f(y) = f(f^{-1}(x)) \iff 3y-8 = f^{-1}(x).\]Since $y = f(x) = 3x-8$, we have \[f^{-1}(x) = 3(3x-8)-8 = 9x-32.\]Therefore \[3y-8=9x-32,\]or $9x = 3y+24$. But we also have $y = 3x-8$, so $9x=9x+8$, or $8=0$. This equation is never true, so there are $\boxed{\text{no values}}$ of $x$ for which $f(x) = f^{-1}(x)$.
